reviews.text: The Shape of Water is a film that wears its heart on its sleeve. Its overtness, its accessibility, the transparent meaning of its abiding images, will surely give it a longevity.
reviews.author: Sophie Monks Kaufman

reviews.text: The beastliness offsets the beauty nicely, like splotches of grisly red on the film's lustrous, sea foam-green color palette.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: The Shape of Water is a breathless film, anchored by [Sally] Hawkins' visible, ardent longing for connection, and her fierce defiance when the things she loves are threatened
reviews.author: Tasha Robinson

reviews.text: With elements of noir, horror, romance and musical filmmaking The Shape of Water provides a heady brew of references, all combining to form a delightful whole.
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: One of [del Toro's] deepest, most complex, most rewarding, and flat-out beautiful films.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: No one loves monsters as much as Guillermo Del Toro, and his love seeps into every pore of The Shape of Water.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: Guillermo del Toro's masterpiece.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: "The Shape of Water" combines a creature feature and a melodrama to tell a beautiful story that will thrill as much as get you emotional.
reviews.author: Jason Guerrasio

reviews.text: The Shape of Water may be a bit weird and jarring to most, but it played to me like a beautiful and whimsical love story that anyone can relate to. Especially to those who do feel like outliers to what love is supposed to look like.
reviews.author: Jamie Broadnax

reviews.text: The Shape of Water is a very special movie.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: It is hard to over-state how good Hawkins is in this role. Speech is an actor's most potent weapon, but she gives a masterclass in how you to move and charm an audience without it.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: The Shape of Water is one of the most delightful films of the year. And it is definitely the best film ever to be a romantic comedy, a melodrama, a spy thriller, a heist caper, a superhero blockbuster and a monster movie all at once.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber

reviews.text: The Shape of Water is as strange and brave as people can be strange and brave, especially the quiet ones, the weird ones you don't think that much about.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: ...magical, old fashioned cinema, which proves to be vibrant, delightful escapism rich with emotion and significance.
reviews.author: Greg Dolgopolov

reviews.text: Guillermo del Toro's The Shape of Water is that big romantic all-out imaginative coup (with a sly political undercurrent) that so many of us have been waiting for from the director.
reviews.author: Nick James

reviews.text: If you can imagine an aggressively adorable -- and somewhat effortful -- version of Amélie in which our hero f---s the Creature from the Black Lagoon, you're totally feeling this.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: In order to enjoy the myriad pleasures of del Toro's world - with all its counterpointed humor, quicksilver pacing, endearing humanity, peculiar eroticism, and sudden eruptions of violence - one must simply take the plunge.
reviews.author: Rory O'Connor

reviews.text: Deeply satisfying filmmaking at its best. It's witty, smart and brilliantly played, plumbing the sub-aqueous depths of our psyches, our histories and desires.
reviews.author: John Bleasdale

reviews.text: Simply monumental, monstrous, political and poetic. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Martínez

reviews.text: A sublime cross between the fantastic and the romantic; Without having to have a young woman who follows the canon of beauty of catwalk. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alejandro G. Calvo

reviews.text: There's enough magic, and extraordinary visual imagination, to smooth the edges of the movie's problems.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: The Shape of Water may just be his most touching fantasy yet.
reviews.author: David Sexton

reviews.text: It offers what must be cinema's uneasiest probing of the postwar American psyche since Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master - and is unquestionably del Toro's best, richest film since his 2006 Spanish-language masterpiece Pan's Labyrinth.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: The Shape of Water casts a spell over its audience from its opening moments and holds you in its thrall long after the credits have rolled.
reviews.author: Marlow Stern

reviews.text: For all the veering from one genre to another, neither does it feel rough. Del Toro's tight directorial control sees to that.
reviews.author: Ben Croll

reviews.text: This is a monster movie but it plays like a Beauty and the Beast-style romance.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: A charming, beautifully filmed movie that appeals on many levels and is a song to cinema and to love.
reviews.author: Jo-Ann Titmarsh

reviews.text: Guillermo del Toro channels all the streams that make him unique into The Shape Of Water, pouring his heart, soul and considerable craft into an exquisite creature fable.
reviews.author: Fionnuala Halligan

reviews.text: A ravishing, eccentric auteur's imagining, spilling artistry, empathy and sensuality from every open pore, it also offers more straight-up movie for your money than just about any Hollywood studio offering this year.
reviews.author: Guy Lodge

reviews.text: It's a film that makes you feel a lot, but overridingly you feel lucky - lucky to be watching it, lucky that something so sincerely sweet, sorrowfully scary and surpassingly strange can exist in this un-wonderful world.
reviews.author: Jessica Kiang

reviews.text: A dark-edged fairy tale as lovingly steeped in vintage movie magic as it is in hypnotic water imagery, this captivating creature feature marries a portrait of morally corrupt early-1960s America with an outsider tale of love and friendship ...
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: Del Toro provides just enough spade-work to keep the scheme plausible and his film is stylish and charming; red meat for the senses with some sugar on top.
reviews.author: Xan Brooks

reviews.text: The Shape of Water not only entertains as a sumptuous fairytale, but it reinforces a faith in humanity set in a time where tolerance of other races, nationalities, and non-"family values" love was volatile. And it's percolating back to the surface again.
reviews.author: Brian Formo

reviews.text: There's something here for lovers of all kinds of movies - even silents and musicals - but del Toro transcends mere pastiche to craft a work that feels like the product of our collective film-going subconscious.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

synopsis: Elisa is a mute, isolated woman who works as a cleaning lady in a hidden, high-security government laboratory in 1962 Baltimore. Her life changes forever when she discovers the lab's classified secret -- a mysterious, scaled creature from South America that lives in a water tank. As Elisa develops a unique bond with her new friend, she soon learns that its fate and very survival lies in the hands of a hostile government agent and a marine biologist.
